definitions.example: They sell feed, riding helmets, and everything else for horses.

definitions.definition: The part of a machine that supplies the material to be operated upon.
definitions.example: the paper feed of a printer

definitions.definition: The forward motion of the material fed into a machine.
A gathering to eat, especially in quantity.
definitions.example: They held a crab feed on the beach.

definitions.definition: Encapsulated online content, such as news or a blog, that can be subscribed to.
definitions.example: I've subscribed to the feeds of my favourite blogs, so I can find out when new posts are added without having to visit those sites.

definitions.definition: (ditransitive) To give (someone or something) food to eat.

definitions.example: Spiders feed on gnats and flies.

definitions.definition: To give (someone or something) to (someone or something else) as food.
definitions.example: Feed the fish to the dolphins.

definitions.definition: To give to a machine to be processed.
definitions.example: Feed the paper gently into the document shredder.

definitions.definition: To satisfy, gratify, or minister to (a sense, taste, desire, etc.).
To graze; to cause to be cropped by feeding, as herbage by cattle.
definitions.example: If grain is too forward in autumn, feed it with sheep.

definitions.definition: (of a phonological rule) To create the environment where another phonological rule can apply; to be applied before another rule.
(of a syntactic rule) To create the syntactic environment in which another syntactic rule is applied; to be applied before another syntactic rule.
To reward for services performed, or to be performed; to recompense; to hire or keep in hire; hence, to bribe.
